title: What's you're favorite slab serif?
content:
Currently I'm in love with [**Archer**](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.typography.com/fonts/font_overview.php?productLineID=100033). Now it's your turn… ready, set, go!

Matt
author: Maverick18x

comments.content: i'm saving up for soho
[Enclave](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.terminaldesign.com/fonts/sets/?CID=6)
Psst … if you are rather on the humanistic route, and don’t need italics: [Silica](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.stonetypefoundry.com/silicaoverview.html).
I like the look of Silica. And I think [Amasis](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.ascenderfonts.com/font/amasis-family.aspx) is real nice.
I've got a few favorites but none of them have been released yet.

I guess that isn't entirely true. I do like [Vista Slab](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=vista+slab&x=0&y=0). I think [Rayuela](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/pampatype/rayuela/) is more of a hybrid slab, but the chocolate weight gets me. I've used [Giza](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/Giza) and [Cholla](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/emigre/cholla_slab/) several times. And I've had my eyes on [FF Zine](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=ff+zine&x=0&y=0) and [Dispatch](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/slab/Dispatch) too.

So many huh? I like the good and old STYMIE

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/stymie](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/stymie "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/stymie")

out of ones I own: Clarendon  
out of ones i wish i owned: Archer
And I agree. I wish I did have a license for Archer too.

[Joanna](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.linotype.com/885/joanna-family.html)

2 x 2 = 5

Overall, I guess I'd use Silica, but Caecilia italic is great. The roman is fine, but the italic is charming and lively, particularly at large sizes. Well, I guess all slabs work better at large sizes.

If you include it as a slab, Chapparal is terrific and CAN work at small sizes because of optical sizes. Pricey, though.

[Black Slabbath](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.youworkforthem.com/product.php?sku=t0133)

\m/

Also, [Brioni](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.typotheque.com/fonts/brioni_text/) is lovely. Sort of reminds me of Caecilia in a way that probably has nothing to do with type and everything to do with <cite>Atonement</cite>.

I enjoy that James Montalbano likes Enclave...

Actually, \*I\* like it, too and appreciate being reminded about it. It has the forthrightness of slabs without the heavy handedness. That may well be a purchase in the new year.

I've been waiting for a thread like this! :P  
I've been thinking about slabs; I think there's a shortage of nice slabs… most of them look a bit off, to me, like those old ones, [Rockwell](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.linotype.com/1409/rockwell-family.html) and [Stymie](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.linotype.com/90275/stymie-family.html). [Serifa](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.linotype.com/1463/serifa-family.html) is kind of nice, but I think those three work best when setting all caps. Not to mention the fact that they lack cursive italics. Anyway, I for one love [Caecilia](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.linotype.com/1313/pmncaecilia-family.html). And what about [TheSerif](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/lucasfonts/theserif_classic/)? And [Officina Serif](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/elsner_flake/itc_officina_serif/)?  
I didn't know some of these you all mentioned, but none of them really won me over… Vista was almost begging to become a slab, that's a great one (I love Vista, so I love [Vista Slab](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=vista+slab&x=0&y=0)), and [Black Sabbath](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.youworkforthem.com/product.php?sku=t0133) is great in that quirky glitchy way. Should make some sweet posters!  
But I see a possibility, here… I really need to start working on a slab. :P

Unit Slab will be pretty sweet when we're done with it.

--K
[Apex Serif](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/vllg.com/Thirstype/ApexSerif/mudTyper+Weights/)
United Serif (assuming it qualifies)
Archer!
No love for Lubalin Graph?

I've used Chapparal a number of times, and continue to admire it very much. It is a very comfortable read, which is more than can be said for most slab serifs, which tend towards stiffness and lack of interaction between letters.

I've just seen the newly released [Brioni](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.typotheque.com/data/specimens/pdf/BrioniStd_BrioniTextStd_info.pdf) [PDF link] from Nikola Djurec, and it seems to me a clever piece of work.

I've recently used Chaparral for the first time directing this graduation catalogue publication and everybody was happy (you can see a section here, . [pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/homes.ieu.edu.tr/~asegalini/0708/gpj-gallery.pdf)).

I'm a fan of [Giza](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/Giza), as you can see from my icon. :-) [Ziggurat](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.typography.com/fonts/font_overview.php?productLineID=100028&itemID=200056&cpuCount=) is also on my list of favorite slabs.
Chapparal!
I think Chaparral is great, somehow the angles soften things a bit and make me forget it's really a slab serif.
So who is creating a [Slab Serif](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Slab%20Serif) wiki page?

Hellenic.  
 [http://www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=JBT0000094](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=JBT0000094 "http://www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=JBT0000094")
kris : is there any sketches available for us to look at?
I really enjoy Glypha. It is really smooth and is pretty versatile.

\>So who is creating a Slab Serif wiki page?  
Then don't forget PMN Caecilia.  
Of course Clarendon rules all of this "genre", hehe

Hey vicone, no sketches but here is a screenie of the weights:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147im_/http:/typophile.com/files/USlab_roman_3964.gif)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147im_/http:/typophile.com/files/USlab_italic_5107.gif)

I have used Caecilia and Serifa for some projects, I also like Glypha.  
And now I am saving for Unit slab...

Wow, a lot of great fonts on this page. I really like the more geometrical slabs like:

[Stag](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/vllg.com/Schwartzco/Stag/mudTyper+Weights/)

[Prelo Slab](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.dstype.com/prelo_slab.html)

[Guardian Egyptian](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/christianschwartz.com/gdnegyp.shtml) Unfortunately not for sale

[Polular](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/christianschwartz.com/popular.shtml) Unfortunately not for sale

And FF ZIne and Lubalin Graph, which I have used for many projects.

I really think Archer can't be a great and new alternative to the very used Serifa, Rockwell, Stymie etc. but I wish they would make a black/heavy weight of the font. Has anyone heard of plans of this? With Gotham they released a black version some time after the initial release.

Oh, and speaking of Black Slabbath have you seen [Facebuster](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.typetrust.com/fonts/font.php?id=NzQ3)?

I have to say, still have a soft spot for good ol’ Rockwell and Memphis, although they lend a definite historical note. Lubalin Graph is so much like a slab-serif version of Avant Garde I can only use it in a similar way, and it’ll be a few years before I want to go that route! For a more modern feel I quite like Enclave.

Don't have it but as I saw it just recently am currently in lust with Archer.

Since it was mentioned: Guardian Egyptian I've been seeing a lot of lately (partner’s newspaper) and I don’t like the light, but the italics I loathe. Overall I really don’t like the way they use it.

Personally I don’t really feel that bracketed serifs really belong in the same class as what I think of when I hear _slab serif_ so definitely no Clarendon for me.
I just thought of Rockwell again this morning and was surprised nobody had mentioned it yet. I know it's used a lot, but I think it's an absolutely classic slab serif.

It has been mentioned. Multiple times. Including the two posts directly before your latest.

If you are going to start a thread it would be polite to read the replies.

Therese, I've subscribed to the RSS feed of every thread I've ever started on typophile. As far as I know, nobody had mentioned it yet when I checked my feed reader this morning. I just found it interesting that I'd think of it, go out the door, and see two posts relating to it when I returned home. Maybe you misunderstood me.
Actually, the first time it was mentioned was on the 18th. Maybe you should get a new feed reader.

i have to agree with peter, Stag is amazing, i use it all the time, and Prelo Slab and Guardian Egyptian look great, and i'm seriously thinking of getting Facebuster... i just can't think of a use for it right away... oh and yes, archer looks amazing too!

of the more 'classic' slabs, i like Rockwell... a
I love the strict geometry of Lubalin Graph, but after recently working with the typeface on a job, I have to give it up for Caecilia. Very clean, without looking too turgid.
Aptifer. Too bad I never get to use it.

[Prelo](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.typetrust.com/fonts/font.php?id=NTcz&fontview=specimen) does look pretty good, strange that I had never noticed it, seeing as it's one of the only portuguese slab-serifs. There's also [Morgan Avec](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.felicianotypefoundry.com/main/?page_id=188), but I think Prelo is more to my taste. Also, I just thought of [Nexus Mix](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_nexus_mix/), which might be a nice, different choice.  
Nice suggestions from everybody! Reminds me why we DO need typophile… :P

i've heard about neutra slab being in the works... now that sounds great, but i haven't seen any sketches or anything... maybe if christian or someone from house is on here they could give us an update? \*wink wink\* :-)

Simon: [Neutra 'Slab'](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/wildflour.co.nz/pdf/wild-flour-tapas-menu-06-2008.pdf) (PDF link) courtest of Kris Sowersby.

I prefer Archer :)

It seems there is a certain 'renaissance' for the Slab, perhaps especially for the more humanist ones. Would you agree? Or am I reading too much into my own current predilection, seeing slabs just about everywhere?
Last May a colleague wanted me to spot a typeface he loved, from The Central Saint Martin College of Art & Design, 1999 BA degree show catalogue ; it was ITC Officina Serif.

Archer, easy.

- Scott Sullivan  
 [www.trifepdgm.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.trifepdgm.com/ "www.trifepdgm.com")

I'll add [Lexia](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.daltonmaag.com/browse/fonts/dama/lexia) and [Farao](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.fountain.nu/catalogue/ftn_farao_reg.asp) to the mix. I really love Farao -- just wish I could use it more. Something similar to Farao (without the worn edges) that I've used is [Quadra 57](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/berthold/quadra-57-bq/regular/).
What about [FF Tisa](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218044147/http:/tdc.org/news/2007Results/Tisa.html)?
